# Task

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.



# Data

df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"],
    model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])
audi_filter(df_cars)

# Solution

```julia
function audi_filter(df::DataFrame)
    mask = df.manufacturer .== "audi" && (df.model .== "a4" || df.model .== "a4 quattro")
    filtered_df = filter(mask, df)
    
    # Add new column with `true` across all rows
    filtered_df[:audi_a4_type] = true
    
    return filtered_df
end
```

# Checking the Solution

```julia
using Test

@testset "Audi Filter" begin
    expected_df = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "audi", "audi"],
        model=["a4", "a6", "a4 quattro", "tt"],
        audi_a4_type=[true, true, true, true])
    @test audi_filter(df_cars) == expected_df
end
```

# Output

The output DataFrame should match the following:

| manufacturer | model      | audi_a4_type |
|--------------|------------|--------------|
| audi         | a4        | true         |
| audi         | a6        | false        |
| audi         | 3 series   | false        |
| audi         | a4 quattro | true         |
| audi         | q7        | false        |
| ford         | fusion    | false        |
| audi         | tt        | true         |
| audi         | a4        | true         |
| toyota       | corolla   | false        |
| audi         | a4 quattro | true         |
